Feeling numb: Simon Amstell

28/05/2012

Ex-host of Buzzcocks and Popworld, Simon Amstell, talks to Ally Swadling about his stand-up, his sitcom and not being miserable. (Thumbnail credit Simon Amstell. Photo credit: seekernews)

Image by

By undefined undefined

I've read countless times that comedian and scathing inquisitor Simon Amstell, dislikes interviews. "Well I try to find the best in them," he responds tentatively as I immediately apologise about the nature of our talk. "But I think this will be a wonderful experience for everyone involved", he perks up.There's nothing to fear, I'm no Amstell, but I do inform him that his Popworld cropped hair was a bit shit. "Oh my god, are you bitch-slapping me?" he laughs normally. I laugh nervously. There is plenty of laughter throughout our conversation - I don't think it's entirely nervous, but I am slightly apprehensive interviewing someone who is renowned for being such a master of derision. However, this Amstell is calm. He's also sensitive and insightful, but often prone to the odd cackling outburst which I enjoy immensely. Since he was 18, Amstell has been forging the kind of silly scathing persona he is now so readily associated with. Starting out as a presenter on Nickelodeon, Amstell was allegedly later sacked for being "sarcastic and mean to children" and moved on to Channel 4's Popworld where he refined his infamous irreverent interviewing technique. After six years at Popworld, Amstell became the permanent and popular host of Buzzcocks where he quickly established himself as everyone's favourite human being when he provoked wet sock Preston to infamously storm off the pop quiz. Amstell left Buzzcocks in 2009, due to what he describes as boredom: "I think the problem with it was really, I would sit down and say to people - 'Welcome to the show', and they would say, 'Go on, what you gonna say?' And at that point you can't do it, it would be impossible. It was partly boredom, but also it just wasn't going to be possible to keep doing it the way I was doing it." His decision to leave the quiz was unpopular, but Amstell's sitcom Grandma's House has given him the space to express little self-contempt and do a little soul-searching. "It sort of feels more helpful for me as well - more morally acceptable. It's good. I think attacking myself is a better way to go for a while." Grandma's House, which Amstell co-wrote and stars in, follows a man called Simon who became famous for mocking pop stars on the telly, but then gets bored and tries to be an actor. Uncanny. "It is fiction, but it all comes from a real emotion," he reflects. "So, if the actual event we've written about in the show isn't based on actual life it'll come from a feeling that we need to express in some way... Does that make sense?" Amstell is often quite careful of what he's saying - it's this kind of self-awareness that is most striking about his recent comic endeavours, especially Grandma's House. While the sitcom's clever self-referential humour and pervasive sense of despair may be tres cool and post-modern, Grandma's House also thrives on the simple silliness of Amstell's hilarious fruit-loop family, its numerous Yiddishisms and his own painful awkwardness. "We definitely took all the worst elements of me and put them into a character" he smiles. So do you feel like you're acting in the show? "Well yes..." Amstell responds a little confused. "I had to pretend to be sad sometimes when I'd just been eating my lunch and wasn't sad. I had to memorise the lines, I had to do the stuff that actors do." I thank him for explaining to me how acting works. "Hahaha! Sorry that wasn't what I meant." It wasn't really what I meant either, but I choose not to dwell on some of the criticism that has been made about his acting - especially since he is so enthusiastic about his recent film role playing psychiatrist Eric Sacks in the British comedy, Black Pond. "It was really fun to play somebody other than myself, that was quite freeing. And watching it as well - I've never seen myself on a cinema screen before and I thought, oh god, my face should always be that big." Have you always wanted to act, or is this your new thing? He hesitates a little. "You know, when we were at the early writing stages of Grandma's House, I'd sort of written myself into it, but I was very nervous about the whole thing. I thought if we actually get to do this then I'm going to have to be this. I kept suggesting other actors that could play me, but the producers seem to think I had a unique quality that was very important to capture" Amstell sniggers. "So yeah, it was only really through writing the stuff and having such a lack of imagination that I can't write about anything other than myself." However Amstell hasn't completely turned inwards, as his family also don't escape his mocking touch, especially his mother who is depicted as neurotic and totally fame-obsessed. Reading between the lines of Amstell's early CV--appearing on GamesMaster in 1993 then onGood Morning with Anne and Nick with his Dame Edna impression and later in his early teens as a hopeful magician on Family Catchphrase--it is not difficult to see where the inspiration for his on-screen mother's character may have come from. "She's both ridiculously proud and horrified by it. She tells me she hears herself saying things now and thinks its Rebecca Front saying them" Amstell explains, describing his actual mother's response. "And also she'll say things to me now, and I'll say to her - 'You know that's already a line in the first series. You're just repeating things.' And then she apologises and promises to give me new material instead" he chuckles. Although Amstell has no intention of making a third series of Grandma's House -- "I think I've written all the pain out of me" -- his latest stand-up tour, Numb, continues on the uplifting theme of self-abasement. "Well at the root of it seems to be my own pain and misery, but I think that won't always be the case. I think the comedy comes from an optimism about that, and having the perspective that it's all sort of ridiculous, because we're all going to die. It's not like a miserable show, people come away-" Crying? "No! Feeling a bit better and feeling connected to somebody or something. I think there's an honesty about it. To me, I'd feel disconnected if I watched people smiling in a fake way on television, I feel like none of this is real, but having a real human being that's saying something that's coming from somewhere true that feels uplifting and like there's something life-affirming and good." Isn't it terrifying opening up on stage? "I wouldn't say it was terrifying." Okay, I would find it terrifying. "I like that. I feel quite safe opening to people on stage, but also in real life sometimes" he laughs. Since Amstell's last tour in 2009, Do Nothing, a lot has changed. Although still as tormented, Amstell appears to have a peaceful destination in mind. "Well I've changed quite a lot, I think. Although we always think we're improving as human beings, but usually it's a terrible illusion, but I think I am different" he explains. "The show's a bit of a journey. I start as an awkward mess then by the end I've sort of found some peace in the world, so it's quite a good journey for any awkward outsider weirdos to come and see." He continues. "I sort of want to connect with people. I want them to feel like there's a human being talking to them on stage, not just a guy in a big suit, to be able to come to something where something really happened and heard something and really connected to them as a human being. I suppose I do that by being the most truthful and open that I can be." Aww... Amstell cackles. I ask him briefly about his attempt with actress Jessie Cave to get to grips with Twitter. He is a very polite tweeter. "I've decided it's a mailing list" he laughs. "If anyone wants to know any more than that, I'm not the guy who's going to provide comments about sandwiches - it's just not going to happen. I tend to sort of save up what I think is going to be valuable to say on a stand-up show like this one. So, if anyone wants to come and watch me do an hour's worth of brilliant tweets, then that's what will happen." But Amstell is not that contrived. He tells me about how his stand-up comes into being - going onstage with some bullet points on a piece of paper and then plenty of trial and error. Consequently, his stand-up is incredibly honest and uncensored - "it just becomes what it becomes" he tells me. Looking at Amstell's career, he seems to be several different people: brazen presenter, vulnerable, sexually awkward actor, insightful Buddhist comedian. But what works for Amstell--what makes him so endearing and funny--is undoubtedly his honesty. "We're all very different people - you're a different person with your mother than how you are with your lover, hopefully. So it's difficult, it's very difficult, but I try my best to have as much self-awareness as possible for this stuff to work." Simon Amstell will be performing at the York Grand Opera House on 31st May.
